awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Response to Environmental Alteration on the US Great Plains
awd_abstract_narration:
Periods of extreme aridity and drought pose significant challenges to humans and the resources on which they depend. Under the direction of Dr. David Meltzer, Ryan Breslawski will undertake research to understand how past peoples responded to one especially severe and long-lasting episode of aridity and drought on the North American Great Plains: the Altithermal, which took place ca. 8,000 to 5,000 years ago. Importantly, while aridity and drought are challenges to human societies, their effects are rarely uniform over large geographic areas, and thus a diversity of human adaptive responses may develop, especially in foraging societies lacking domesticated foods. Did geographic variability in Altithermal aridity and drought drive subsistence variability across space in past foraging societies? Can this variability be linked to declines in the availability of prey animals? Archaeology is an essential tool for resolving these questions and clarifying the processes through which human societies have adapted over millennia. The investigators will explore these questions through work with past bison hunting peoples on the Great Plains. Results from the project will shed light not only on Great Plains prehistory, but also on the effects of climate change on North America’s grasslands. Millions of people depend on the Greats Plains ecosystem today, as does the ongoing recovery of the iconic American bison. As climate change continues, the full picture of its past impacts on the Great Plains will only become more relevant.

Previous research suggests that 8000–5000 years ago much of western North America experienced hyperaridity and drought. Overall, surface water became scarce, vegetation cover decreased, and animal populations declined. However, not all areas were impacted in similar ways or to the same degree, and human responses to these impacts would not have been uniform throughout the region. Regional variation in these impacts and the human responses to them remain poorly documented. Further, much remains to be learned about how bison, a vital resource for Great Plains peoples, were impacted by Altithermal drought and aridity, and the degree to which these impacts were mediated by geography. To resolve these issues, the project will analyze bison remains from over two dozen previously excavated archaeological sites dating to this period and located throughout the Great Plains.The project will collect data on the butchery activities of past human hunters represented by each set of bison remains, as well as data on the environmental stresses experienced by these prey animals. Environmental stresses will be examined through dental defects that result from malnutrition, and through the stable isotope chemistry of teeth, which reflects the food and water that past bison consumed. The results will be used to identify potential links between geographic variability in climate change, bison population declines, and human responses to those declines during this period of extreme aridity and drought.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Middle Holocene (8200-5000 years ago) was an especially hot and dry period on the North American Great Plains. At this time, the region's Indigenous foraging peoples expanded into new food resources and developed new food processing technologies. It is unclear precisely what drove these cultural changes, although environmental explanations tend to assume that climate change played a strong role, with declining water availability and reduced animal populations being key factors. A decline in one such animal, bison, has been previously proposed as the mechanism that drove the adoption of new resources and technologies. Such declines were likely mediated by latitude, with animal populations in the south declining disproportionately relative to the north or disappearing entirely. Such a decline would have prompted people to pursue other resources, and, potentially, to spend more time butchering what few bison they could find. However, the geography of Middle Holocene bison population variability has yet to be firmly established. Further, it is unclear whether variability in butchering time actually tracked this population variability.

To evaluate whether the availability of bison was responsible for subsistence variability in the Middle Holocene, this project examined bison remains from sites dating to the Middle and preceding Early Holocene (10,000-8200 years ago). This entailed first assessing spatio-temporal variability in bison population sizes, then evaluating subsistence responses to that variability. A reliable proxy measure of bison population sizes is lacking, and this project therefore assumed a link between bison population size and habitat suitability. First, stable oxygen isotope ratios and rates of linear enamel hypoplasia (LEH) in bison teeth were analyzed to understand geographic and temporal variability in habitat suitability. The former variable was used as a proxy measure of atmospheric temperature, where warmer temperatures exerted more stress on these animals. The latter variable records cases of physiological stress, where the incidence rate of hypoplasia increases as grassland conditions deteriorate and populations decline. The researcher expected that suitability declined from the Early to Middle Holocene, and that the magnitude of this decline was negatively associated with latitude.

Next, the project assessed whether declines in bison population sizes prompted Middle Holocene peoples to expend more time butchering each hunted animal. Longer butchering time may result from more extensive extraction of bone marrow or more thorough rendering of bone grease, both of which lead to higher levels of bone fragmentation. To evaluate this prediction, the project examined spatial variability in bison bone fragmentation patterns in the Middle Holocene, with the expectation that fragmentation should increase toward the south alongside evidence for declining habitat suitability.

The resulting oxygen isotope data indicate that Middle Holocene warming was most pronounced at southern latitudes, and that the Canadian prairies and northernmost U.S. grasslands experienced little to no change in average temperature compared to the Early Holocene. However, isotope data only extend as far south as Kansas, leaving the true severity of Middle Holocene warming on the southern Plains unknown (i.e., in Texas, Oklahoma, and New Mexico). Warming at southern latitudes was a winter phenomenon, which would have adversely grass biomass, the availability of drinking water, and possibly prey predictability. The incidence of LEH was too low to detect spatio-temporal patterns in the dataset, and these data could not be used to evaluate predictions about habitat suitability.

Observed long bone fragmentation is consistent with longer butchering times at northern latitudes, contradicting expectations. These data support the hypothesis that Middle Holocene warming was primarily a southern phenomenon, and that the decline of bison in this period was likely restricted to the central and southern areas of the region. However, the motivations for increased butchering time appear unrelated to bison population levels within the Middle Holocene. People spent the most time processing these animals where they were most abundant, contrary to theoretical expectations. Rather, these motivations likely arose from factors relating to trade or social incentives, where increased butchering time allowed for the production of pemmican that could be stored or traded. These processes had consequences for the continued historical trajectories of subsistence economies into the Late Holocene and historic period. Much like the Middle Holocene, North America's modern grasslands are warming, imperiling the social and ecological systems that support bison and the people who depend on them. A better grasp on the relationship between bison and climate change in the Middle Holocene holds potential lessons for the persistence of these animals today.
